Research

I’m a final year PhD candidate in the Department of Statistics and Data Science at Carnegie Mellon University. I’m extremely fortunate to be advised by Prof. Matey Neykov.

Broadly speaking my primary research interests focus on

Developing various generalizations of models and estimators in classical statistics, and analyzing their theoretical properties.

More specifically, the classical topics I study include density estimation, isotonic regression, and location-scale estimation. I’m also actively interested in application-based methodology via statistical ranking (in particular the Bradley-Terry-Luce model), and spatiotemporal modeling (wildfire prediction).

I particularly enjoy the collaborative aspect of research, and I’m privileged to work with the following brilliant people1: Heejong Bong, Niccolò (Nic) Dalmasso, Riccardo Fogliato, Arun Kumar Kuchibhotla, Wanshan Li, Matey Neykov, Alessandro (Ale) Rinaldo.

I recommend just perusing some of my papers below to get a better idea of the type of problems I like to work on, and the style of papers I enjoy writing with my co-authors.

If you’d like to work on a problem together, feel free to reach out. I’m always open to discussing new research directions, and applying statistics to solve problems in new and interesting domains!

Under Review

Revisiting Le Cam’s Equation: Exact Minimax Rates over Convex Density Classes
Shamindra Shrotriya, Matey Neykov (2022).

arxiv pdf

We study the classical problem of deriving minimax rates for density estimation over convex density classes. Building on the pioneering work of Le Cam (1973), Birge (1983, 1986), Wong and Shen (1995), Yang and Barron (1999), we determine the exact (up to constants) minimax rate over any convex density class. This work thus extends these known results by demonstrating that the local metric entropy of the density class always captures the minimax optimal rates under such settings. Our bounds provide a unifying perspective across both parametric and nonparametric convex density classes, under weaker assumptions on the richness of the density class than previously considered. Our proposed ‘multistage sieve’ MLE applies to any such convex density class. We apply our risk bounds to rederive known minimax rates including bounded total variation, and Holder density classes. We further illustrate the utility of the result by deriving upper bounds for less studied classes, e.g., convex mixture of densities.


Adversarial Sign-Corrupted Isotonic Regression
Shamindra Shrotriya, Matey Neykov (2022).
